posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked:
Team 141 has been developing a vision program, WOBOT 2020 Vision, that uses LabVIEW to capture an process camera images. This software will collect and process images that contain AprilTags and any other targets. It is very simple to use with any USB camera. We use an onboard laptop to process the images and send the data to the NT tables as well as direct TCP communication to the RoboRIO. This software also sends data directly to the driver station software.  This is our release of this software so we can use it again next year.

GitHub - WOBOT-141/Wobot-Vision-2020: Vision Software Vision Software

Vision Software

Here are some advantages of this software:

No need to buy propitiatory hardware.

Connect as many cameras as you want (color or black and white) and still maintain frame rates on the cameras.

We are seeing frame rates of 40FRS on a single loop for the AprilTag processing at 640 X 480. 20FPS at 1900 X 1304. with the yaw, pitch and roll for each tag found sent in an array.

We have multiple target loops running on one vision system that can handle all of the camera and processing. ApriTags Balls Coral

ApriTags

Balls

Coral

We have seem frame rates and processing as high as 180 FPS at full resolution (1600 X 1304) for reflective tape tracking.

Using a Laptop there is no need to provide power to the vision system. That is mostly why I wanted to be able to use a PC. We were able to run our vision system for three hours without having to recharge the system. As long as we recharged between matches we never had to shut down the vision system for the whole days worth of matches.

If you have questions send me a message and I will answer anything I can.
Just as a heads-up, LabVIEW will no longer work in 2027 due to the new control system.

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked: There is no tie to this software and the controller. LabVIEW will continue to work. It is not dependent on FIRST .

This isn’t quite true. For our application there needs to be deep integration between the software and hardware, and since National Instruments will no longer be developing the robot controller, as well as the amount of LabVIEW teams decreasing every year, it’s highly unlikely that LabVIEW will be supported. Of course you could hack in support for it yourself (I’m pretty sure there’s a team that uses Rust) but it would be much harder, less stable, and more complicated.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
LabView is a programming language.  It can compile to executable files, and can run on numerous systems including Linux.  The Systemcore may not have LabVIEW built in, but that doesn’t mean you can’t use LabVIEW to develop software like this and use it for competition on your driver station, Coprocessors, or potentially even on the Systemcore itself.

I realize most people in FRC think of the LabVIEW robot project as “LabVIEW” - but it isn’t.  It’s just an application written in LabVIEW.

hence

pigrammer:

Of course you could hack in support for it yourself

But it almost certainly won’t be an officially supported robot controller language.

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked:
This code has nothing to do with the controller so I am not understanding why that matters. It provides a TCP stream or an NT table pipe that will provide the data that you need to make decisions with. It would be much that same as Limelight or PhotonVision only no unique hardware is required. Plug in any USB camera set the camera parameters in the software and it is off and running.

Today my team uses JAVA to run the robot. We send the info we need directly to the roboRIO vis TCP/IP. The java code breaks down the TCP packets and does what it needs with the information. We are integrating odometry and path planning. The fact that this data is coming from LabVIEW has nothing to do with the data. It is sending all of the pose information that you would see from any other targeting system.

The fact that we are using a PC to process our images make it much faster than a Raspberry pi or Orange PI and we can have multiple camera running on one system. We can also have multiple target packages running at the same time.  I will be working to integrate more of the filed oriented stuff as we move forward.

Again I am not asking you to use this code. It is required for us to use it next year. If someone finds it useful I am happy to help them understand how to use it.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Have you tried running PV on your laptop instead and comparing performance?

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked:
aeastet:

The fact that we are using a PC to process our images make it much faster than a Raspberry pi or Orange PI and we can have multiple camera running on one system. We can also have multiple target packages running at the same time.

PhotonVision can also run on mini pcs as well, which some teams have done before.

With Orange Pi 5 and Raspberry Pi 5, you can get 120fps with the ov9281 camera.

Multiple cameras can be plugged into both devices as well, with each one running a different pipeline (at least in PhotonVision).

aeastet:

Using a Laptop there is no need to provide power to the vision system. That is mostly why I wanted to be able to use a PC. We were able to run our vision system for three hours without having to recharge the system. As long as we recharged between matches we never had to shut down the vision system for the whole days worth of matches.

Is that necessary though? I feel like it is a good idea to shut down the vision computer from time to time to reduce the risk of software glitches.

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked:
I have not tried using PV on a PC. This has been a fun side project since moving to a new team that did not use LabVIEW. I can see about compiling something that will run on a PC and see if I can get a performance metric between the two systems. I really made the LabVIEW version to make it as simple as I could for someone to use. You still need to understand the camera you are using but everything else is simple. Plug in a camera set it up with the frame rate, size and exposures that you want to run. Set he target package to the camera you want to use and setup the camera info.

I am open for any issues that are found or any improvements that need to be made. My original purpose was to build something that can use the tools you probably already have without spending money to get a vision system. I will see if I can find time to do an evaluation but we are still busy working on new project for next year.

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked:
PhotonVision can also run on mini pcs as well, which some teams have done before.

With Orange Pi 5 and Raspberry Pi 5, you can get 120fps with the ov9281 camera.

Multiple cameras can be plugged into both devices as well, with each one running a different pipeline (at least in PhotonVision).

We are able to run the camera as fast as it is rated to run on our system. That is much different than the number of frames that you can process through the target package. I am able to see full frame rates of over 200 FPS when running some of our cameras at full 4K resolution. That really depends on the camera. For the frame rate from the target package, we see slower frame rates. When using the reflective tape I was able to process images at 180FPS from the camera where we get 200FPS. For the Apriltag cameras we are using global shutter cameras that max out around 60 FPS because I am not able to get the NI provided code to go faster than that. I do have code that I made to find the April tag where I am able to achieve 80FPS but it does not do as good of a job finding oblique angle tags.

Is that necessary though? I feel like it is a good idea to shut down the vision computer from time to time to reduce the risk of software glitches.

It my not be necessary. I have been doing this a long time. One of the issues I had with some of the robots over the years was brownouts on the system when the robot is pushing everything to the limits. I no longer have to worry about what the robot is doing. The vision system runs independently.

As far as having glitches we have run all of our competitions this year without restarting the vision system. We only had one glitch in the six competitions. I made a change to the software after that and I have not seen any glitches since.

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked:
The problem here is not really the frame rates any more. Java is the limiting factor now. The scheduler only runs to 50Hz. Providing frame rates about that are not useful. Using LabVIEW i was able to take advantage of going fast. Java you would have to rip the scheduler apart and make that go faster or you would have to make a new scheduler that would do vision and drive to take advantage of going faster. I am hoping with the new controller we see that the scheduler will run faster. We are looking into how we best use the info we have moving forward at the rates the we receive it.

My long term goal is to be able to run from live images to do targeting and game piece capture. I was able to achieve this on robots running LabVIEW in the past but it seems much harder in Java.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
aeastet:

LabVIEW will continue to work. It is not dependent on FIRST .

NI currently donates licenses to use LabVIEW to FRC teams in the virtual KOP ; there’s no guarantee this will continue past 2026.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
If needed we can create yet another thread for LabVIEW in FRC as a programming language.

Let’s keep this thread on topic please and not let it devolve into a “LabVIEW bad because going away” argument.

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked:
NI currently donates licenses to use LabVIEW to FRC teams in the virtual KOP ; there’s no guarantee this will continue past 2026.

I am in communication with NI about LabVIEW for 2027 and beyond. I have not gotten a commitment from them that they are going to stay involved. You are correct about that. There is a community version of LabVIEW available if NI chooses not to support FIRST moving forward. I am also hoping to have them open the support for FRIST to open source. This would allow for more support for new code. I have been programming with LabVIEW professionally for almost 30 years. I can only hope that NI will start to see the value of FIRST once again now that Emerson has purchased NI. Time will tell.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: PV uses on-coprocessor methods to do pose estimation, which means we’re not limited by the robot code update speed. This means we can get, and thus use, more frequent measurements.

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked:
How fast you can use the data still depends on how your robot processes the data from PV . PV can still only present data to the main robot loop for you to process and do something with. You have to make decisions and tell your drive system do do something after you get the data from PV . That does not change no matter what targeting system you use.

The code i provided also uses multi tread and multi process loops. That will not change how fast your robot can use the information. If you are taking the data into odometery or path planning that will slow it down even more. Part of using all of this stuff is understanding and compensating for the latency that occurs with each step of the process.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Right, I understand that. My point is that pose estimation when done on the coprocessor side benefits from a higher update rate from the cameras. It may be that the robot code can only get pose updates every 20 ms, but a faster camera update rate makes those pose updates more accurate.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
Unfortunately there is no community license for NI’s vision packages, without which you cannot even acquire an image in LabVIEW. If NI drops the free vision license for teams after the 2026 season, any cost advantages of this solution will disappear.

I do think the purpose of this is going to be lost on most here when Photon Vision already exists and LabVIEW has become something of a dirty word in these parts, but it’s neat to develop your own system. As a fellow LabVIEW professional, I appreciate this.

aeastet:

Java you would have to rip the scheduler apart and make that go faster or you would have to make a new scheduler that would do vision and drive to take advantage of going faster.

aeastet:

This isn’t specific to any particular system, but a correction; you are not locked to 20ms loops on the RIO. There are ways built-in to WPILib’s framework to schedule a task at faster speeds. It can be difficult to be sure it will reliably run every 20ms due to the garbage collector if that’s important, but it’s pretty simple to run a loop faster than 20ms nowadays. You don’t need to rip anything apart.

Whether you will see a tangible benefit from fusing vision into pose estimation at a faster rate is another question I’m not personally qualified to answer.

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked:
thatnameistaken:

This isn’t specific to any particular system, but a correction; you are not locked to 20ms loops on the RIO. There are ways built-in to WPILib’s framework to schedule a task at faster speeds. It can be difficult to be sure it will reliably run every 20ms due to the garbage collector if that’s important, but it’s pretty simple to run a loop faster than 20ms nowadays. You don’t need to rip anything apart.

Whether you will see a tangible benefit from fusing vision into pose estimation at a faster rate is another question I’m not personally qualified to answer.

I’m still learning Java. I have a strong team and a few really good programming mentors for text based languages. Since it feels that LabVIEW has become irrelevant in FIRST I am doing my best to stay relevant. You are correct about the vision activation. I am not sure if I build an exe if that will work or not for future versions. I am also working on a version of the code that will not require vision. I have the image collection working. I need to move the image processing away from NI vision. That may take longer and will probably require a different programming language with a wrapper. I have been looking at options for that too.

Since you have LabVIEW experience, I would love to hear what you think about the code I made.
